comments.creator: acelists@atlas.sk
comments.text:
Confirming. If somebody has slow fingers, he could close more tabs than wanted. The rate of closing is really several tabs per second if Ctrl-W is held down. I know tabs can be restored from history, but there is a limit on the number of close tabs remembered and it may also require refetch from network.
On the other hand, Ctrl-T behaves the same way, but that is not a destructive operation.

comments.raw_text: Isn't the keyboard autorepeat rate generally set in the operating system, in the same way as one sets what's considered to be a double click and what is considered to be two distinct mouse clicks? Or doesn't the autorepeat settings effect the rate of Ctrl-W?

comments.text: I believe it is beneficial--repeating is useful in other contexts, but I don't think anyone would actually find it helpful in this one, and in some cases it could be destructive (especially if Firefox is set not to save history).

comments.creator: mozilla@ahlblom.eu
comments.text: I'm probably not an average Firefox user, but I press and hold Ctrl+W quite often. As far as I know there's no good way to delete all tabs in a tab group. Depending on how many hundreds of tabs one has in a tab group it would take a long time to close them all if one has to release Ctrl+W between each of them.
